Clinics upgrading from GentleMax Pro for faster throughput

name: GentleMax Pro

notes: Dual-wavelength Alexandrite + Nd:YAG. Gold standard for versatility. Dynamic Cooling Device (DCD) provides cryogen spray before each pulse.

richContent.overview: Candela's dual-wavelength system combining 755nm Alexandrite and 1064nm Nd:YAG. One of the most widely used professional hair removal lasers worldwide.

Full Fitzpatrick I-VI range with wavelength switching

Clinics often run it alongside newer equipment

typicalUses: Fair to medium skin with dark hair
All body areas: face, underarms, bikini, legs, arms

Also effective for smaller precision areas

name: GentleLase Pro-U

skinTypes.displayText: Lighter skin tones (Alexandrite 755nm). Discuss with your provider if you have darker or tanned skin.

coolingMethod: DCD (Dynamic Cooling Device, cryogen) or ACC (Air Cooling Compatible)

typicalUses: Hair removal on lighter skin types (Fitzpatrick I-III)
Pigmented lesions (age spots, sun damage, freckles)
Vascular lesions (port wine stains)
Practices planning to upgrade to GentleMax Pro dual-wavelength

Optional 20/22/24mm Large Spot Delivery System makes it the fastest standalone Alexandrite hair removal laser. DCD cryogen cooling is operator-independent and scales with fluence, unlike gel-based cooling.

name: GentleYAG

skinTypes.displayText: All skin tones, especially effective for darker skin (Nd:YAG wavelength)

notes: 1064nm Nd:YAG only. Safe for darker skin tones where Alexandrite cannot be used.

richContent.overview: Candela's dedicated 1064nm Nd:YAG laser, designed specifically for safe hair removal on darker skin types (Fitzpatrick V-VI).
richContent.howItWorks: The 1064nm wavelength penetrates deeper and is less absorbed by epidermal melanin, allowing it to reach follicles without overheating darker skin. DCD cooling adds an extra layer of protection.
typicalUses: Darker skin tones that cannot safely use Alexandrite or diode lasers
Also used on tanned patients
richContent.keyFeatures: Fills a critical need for clinics serving diverse populations. Deeper penetration also effective for coarser hair.

name: GentleYAG Pro-U

coolingMethod: DCD (Dynamic Cooling Device, cryogen) or ACC (Air Cooling Compatible)

richContent.overview: Candela's current single-wavelength Nd:YAG platform, the counterpart to the GentleLase Pro-U. Both are upgradeable to the dual-wavelength GentleMax Pro.
richContent.howItWorks: 1064nm Nd:YAG wavelength penetrates deeper and bypasses epidermal melanin, making it safe for darker skin types where shorter wavelengths risk burns. DCD cryogen cooling protects the epidermis before each pulse. Variable pulse durations (0.25–100ms) and spot sizes up to 24mm allow practitioners to customize for hair removal, vascular work, or skin rejuvenation.
typicalUses: Hair removal on darker skin types (Fitzpatrick IV-VI)
Year-round treatment including tanned skin
Vascular lesions (spider veins, leg veins, facial veins, telangiectasia)
Wrinkle reduction and skin rejuvenation
Onychomycosis (nail fungus)
Practices serving diverse populations planning to upgrade to GentleMax Pro

Safe for all skin types including the darkest tones where Alexandrite lasers are contraindicated. 80 joules max delivered energy. Optional 20/22/24mm Large Spot Delivery System for faster large-area treatments. Same DCD cryogen cooling as the entire Gentle Pro series.

name: Nordlys

skinTypes.displayText: Varies by handpiece attachment

richContent.overview: Candela's multi-application aesthetic platform (formerly Ellipse). Hair removal is one of many capabilities, not its primary focus.
richContent.howItWorks: Four technologies in one platform. Hair removal uses SWT (Selective Waveband Technology) IPL handpieces with narrowband filtering across 400–950nm, not a true laser. The Nd:YAG 1064nm module treats vascular lesions. Frax 1550nm and 1940nm modules handle skin resurfacing. Eight different SWT IPL handpieces target different narrow wavelength bands for different skin types and conditions.
typicalUses: Clinics offering diverse treatment menus (rosacea, sun damage, skin tightening) alongside hair removal
richContent.keyFeatures: Versatile across many treatments, but dedicated hair removal devices like the Gentle series may deliver better results for that specific application.

typicalUses: Fast treatment of large body areas (back, chest, legs)
High-volume practices where speed matters
richContent.keyFeatures: Skintel melanin reader removes guesswork from parameter selection. Large spot size significantly reduces treatment time. Older units may still carry the Palomar branding.

richContent.overview: Cynosure's dedicated 755nm Alexandrite laser, built on proven Apogee platform technology. Designed for high fluence with large spot sizes for fast, effective hair removal on lighter skin tones.

typicalUses: Hair removal on Fitzpatrick I-IV
Large body areas (legs, back, chest) with fast treatment times
Clinics that may later upgrade to dual-wavelength Elite+

richContent.keyFeatures: Proven dual-wavelength platform with SmartCool integrated air cooling system.

Clinics with diverse patient populations
richContent.keyFeatures: Proven dual-wavelength technology. Many clinics still run Elite+ systems alongside newer equipment due to their reliability.

Useful for training new practitioners. Skintel guides parameter selection

name: MediLux

skinTypes.displayText: Lighter to medium-dark skin tones. Not recommended for very dark skin (Fitzpatrick VI) — no Nd:YAG laser handpiece available on this platform.

notes: Palomar's original IPL platform and predecessor to the StarLux series. IPL only, unlike the StarLux 300/500/Icon, the MediLux does not support the Lux1064 Nd:YAG laser handpiece. Compatible with IPL handpieces only: LuxR, LuxRs, LuxY, LuxG, LuxB, LuxV. Smooth Pulse technology prevents epidermal temperature spikes. Handpieces rated for 100,000+ pulses: among the most durable in the industry. 48 lbs: extremely compact and portable. Discontinued but still found in budget clinics and on the used market for under $5,000. Palomar acquired by Cynosure in 2015.

richContent.overview: Palomar's first-generation multi-treatment IPL system, launched in the early 2000s. The MediLux established Palomar's handpiece-based platform architecture that would evolve into the StarLux 300, StarLux 500, and eventually the Cynosure Icon. Unlike its successors, the MediLux is pure IPL, it has no laser handpiece option.
richContent.howItWorks: IPL flashlamp delivers broadband light (400–1400nm) filtered through application-specific handpieces. LuxR/LuxRs handpieces filter for hair removal wavelengths, LuxG for vascular/pigmented lesions, LuxV for acne. Smooth Pulse technology eliminates energy spikes that could damage the epidermis, maintaining consistent skin temperature throughout treatment.
typicalUses: Hair removal via IPL (LuxR for large areas, LuxRs for face/bikini)
Photofacials and pigmented lesion treatment (LuxG)
Acne treatment (LuxV)
Budget practices and smaller clinics looking for an affordable multi-treatment system
richContent.keyFeatures: Pure IPL: no laser capability. This is the oldest platform in the Palomar family and does not support the Lux1064 Nd:YAG handpiece available on StarLux and Icon. If a clinic is using a MediLux for hair removal, they are using IPL, not laser. Still encountered in clinics due to its low cost on the used market and the exceptional durability of Palomar handpieces.

skinTypes.displayText: Depends on handpiece. IPL handpieces: Fitzpatrick I-V. Lux1064 Nd:YAG: Fitzpatrick V-VI.

richContent.overview: The original StarLux platform and Palomar's entry into multi-treatment aesthetic systems. Shares the same core handpiece ecosystem as the StarLux 500 for hair removal (LuxR, LuxRs, LuxY, LuxYs, Lux1064) but with a slower cooling system and no fractional laser handpiece compatibility.

typicalUses: Hair removal via IPL handpieces (same as StarLux 500)
Vascular and pigmented lesion treatment
Budget-friendly alternative to StarLux 500 on the used market
Practices with lower patient volume
richContent.keyFeatures: Same consumer advice as StarLux 500: ask which handpiece is used for hair removal. LuxR/LuxY = IPL, Lux1064 = true laser. The 300 is the more affordable used option but has the same core hair removal capabilities. Widely available on the pre-owned market for $5,000-$15,000.

name: StarLux 500

skinTypes.displayText: Depends on handpiece. IPL handpieces (LuxR/LuxY): Fitzpatrick I-V. Lux1064 Nd:YAG handpiece: Fitzpatrick V-VI and tanned skin.

notes: Multi-technology platform combining IPL and laser handpieces on one compact base unit. Hair removal primarily uses IPL handpieces (LuxR for large areas, LuxRs for small areas, LuxY/LuxYs for finer hair). The Lux1064 handpiece is an actual Nd:YAG laser for darker skin types. Over a dozen handpieces available covering hair removal, vascular lesions, pigmented lesions, fractional resurfacing, and skin tightening. Palomar acquired by Cynosure in 2015. Successor: Cynosure Icon. Predecessor: StarLux 300. Many units still in active clinical use despite being discontinued. Palomar's proprietary Photon Recycling and Smooth Pulse technologies. 58 lbs base unit: one of the most compact multi-treatment platforms.

richContent.overview: Palomar's flagship multi-treatment platform, combining IPL and laser technologies via interchangeable handpieces. Widely installed in US clinics from mid-2000s through Cynosure's acquisition in 2015. The StarLux 500 improved on the StarLux 300 with faster cooling (1 minute vs 5+ minutes) and compatibility with additional fractional laser handpieces (Lux1440, Lux1540, Lux2940).
richContent.howItWorks: The base unit delivers optimized pulsed light through application-specific handpieces. For hair removal, IPL handpieces (LuxR, LuxRs, LuxY, LuxYs) use filtered broadband light with AccuSpectrum dual-filter technology to target melanin in hair follicles. The Lux1064 handpiece switches to true Nd:YAG laser for darker skin types. Smooth Pulse technology delivers energy in controlled pulses to prevent epidermal damage. Photon Recycling captures scattered light and redirects it to the target.
typicalUses: Hair removal via IPL handpieces (LuxR for large body areas, LuxRs for face/bikini, LuxY/LuxYs for finer hair)
Hair removal on dark skin via Lux1064 Nd:YAG handpiece
Vascular and pigmented lesion treatment (LuxG, MaxG)
Fractional skin resurfacing (Lux1540, Lux2940)
Practices wanting one platform for multiple treatment types
richContent.keyFeatures: Important: when a clinic says 'we use StarLux for hair removal', ask which handpiece. The LuxR/LuxY handpieces are IPL (not laser). Only the Lux1064 handpiece is a true laser. This is a multi-purpose platform, not purpose-built for hair removal. Succeeded by the Cynosure Icon, which uses upgraded 'Max' handpieces (MaxR, MaxYs, MaxG) on the same platform architecture.

name: Icon

skinTypes.displayText: Depends on handpiece. IPL handpieces (MaxR/MaxYs): Fitzpatrick I-V. 1064+ Nd:YAG: Fitzpatrick V-VI.

richContent.overview: The current-generation evolution of Palomar's StarLux platform, now under Cynosure branding. The Icon maintains the multi-handpiece architecture but with upgraded performance, the addition of Skintel melanin measurement, and enhanced cooling. One of the most versatile multi-treatment platforms on the market, though still primarily IPL-based for hair removal.
richContent.howItWorks: Same core technology as StarLux. Optimized pulsed light delivered through interchangeable handpieces. Max-series handpieces deliver higher peak power with optimized spectral filtering. Skintel melanin reader uses LEDs to calculate objective melanin values for safer parameter settings, removing subjective Fitzpatrick assessment. Advanced Contact Cooling maintains 5°C sapphire tip temperature.
typicalUses: Hair removal via MaxR/MaxRs IPL handpieces (all skin types I-V)
Hair removal on dark skin via 1064+ Nd:YAG handpiece
Photofacial/skin rejuvenation (MaxG handpiece)
Fractional resurfacing for scars and wrinkles (1540, 2940 handpieces)
Skin tightening (Lux Deep IR)
Practices wanting maximum treatment versatility from one platform
richContent.keyFeatures: Same consumer advice applies: the Icon uses IPL handpieces for most hair removal, not laser. The 1064+ handpiece is the only true laser option. The Skintel melanin reader is a genuine safety advantage over competitor IPL systems: it removes guesswork from parameter selection. Cynosure's current multi-platform offering, often found alongside the Vectus (dedicated diode laser) and Elite iQ (dedicated Alexandrite+Nd:YAG laser) in larger practices.

The workhorse of many established practices

ET handpiece: face, bikini, underarms

name: LightSheer INFINITY

coolingMethod: ChillTip (sapphire contact cooling) and vacuum-assisted HIT
notes: First dual-wavelength system in the LightSheer family, adding 1060nm to the established 805nm diode. Three handpieces: HS (22x35mm, vacuum-assisted HIT for large areas, available in both wavelengths), LR (9x27mm, ChillTip sapphire cooling), and ET (9x9mm, ChillTip for small/hard-to-reach areas). Infinity-specific: ET/LR 805nm and HS 805nm handpieces for vascular lesions, PFB, hair removal, pigmented lesions. richContent.overview: The first LightSheer model to offer dual wavelengths. Added the 1060nm diode to the proven 805nm platform, enabling safe year-round treatment of darker and tanned skin types that the single-wavelength LightSheer models couldn't optimally address. Now succeeded by the LightSheer Quattro.

The vacuum-assisted HS handpiece (22x35mm) draws skin closer to the laser source for faster large-area treatment with reduced pain — the vacuum mechanism blocks pain signals by activating tactile and pressure receptors. ChillTip handpieces (ET 9x9mm and LR 9x27mm) use sapphire contact cooling for high-fluence precision work on smaller areas.
typicalUses: Large-area hair removal at speed (legs, back) via vacuum-assisted HS handpiece
Darker and tanned skin types year-round via 1060nm wavelength
Small or hard-to-reach areas (face, bikini) via ET/LR ChillTip handpieces
Vascular lesions and pigmented lesions

Now succeeded by the LightSheer Quattro, but many Infinity units remain in active clinical use.

name: Soprano

richContent.overview: The original Alma Soprano, launched in 2005. The first laser hair removal system to use SHR (Super Hair Removal) technology with In-Motion delivery. This machine introduced the concept of virtually painless laser hair removal through gradual heating at high repetition rates rather than single high-energy pulses.
richContent.howItWorks: Single 810nm diode wavelength with SHR delivery. The handpiece glides continuously across the skin delivering low-fluence pulses at high repetition rates. Contact cooling on the tip protects the epidermis while the dermis is gradually heated to damage the hair follicle.
typicalUses: Largely retired from active service
Some older clinics may still have units in operation
richContent.keyFeatures: Historical significance as the machine that launched Alma's Soprano family and popularized SHR technology worldwide. Single wavelength only (810nm), no Alexandrite or Nd:YAG option. If your clinic uses the original Soprano, it is a legitimate Alma laser but represents technology from 2005. Ask whether they have upgraded to a newer Soprano model.

The practitioner selects the appropriate handpiece based on the patient's skin type: 755nm for lighter skin, 810nm for medium, 1064nm for darker skin. Practices that upgraded from the Soprano XL or XLi to gain multi-wavelength capability

richContent.overview: Launched around 2017, the Soprano ICE Platinum was the first laser to combine three wavelengths (755nm Alexandrite, 810nm Diode, 1064nm Nd:YAG) in a single Trio handpiece that fires all three simultaneously. richContent.howItWorks: The Trio handpiece delivers all three wavelengths simultaneously, targeting different tissue depths and anatomical structures within the hair follicle in a single pass. The 755nm targets the bulge of the follicle (effective for light/fine hair), the 810nm targets the bulge and bulb (deep penetration, general purpose), and the 1064nm targets the bulb and papilla (safest for dark skin). SHR In-Motion delivery uses low-fluence rapid pulses with continuous handpiece movement. ICE sapphire cooling keeps the skin comfortable throughout.
typicalUses: Clinics treating diverse skin types who want one handpiece for all patients
Practices upgrading from the Soprano ICE to eliminate handpiece switching
richContent.keyFeatures: The key innovation over the Soprano ICE is the Trio handpiece: all three wavelengths in one applicator with a 2cm² spot size, versus three separate 1cm² handpieces on the ICE. This means faster treatments, no switching between applicators, and simultaneous multi-depth targeting. However, the Trio spot size (2cm²) is smaller than the Titanium's Trio MAX (4cm²), so treatment times on large areas like legs and back are roughly double what the Titanium achieves. If your clinic uses the ICE Platinum, they have invested in a premium Alma system with proven tri-wavelength technology. It sits just below the Titanium and Titanium SE in Alma's current lineup.

May also appear marketed as 'Alpha Magma Spark Pro' on reseller sites. This is the predecessor/sibling to the Alpha, which added IPL back into the mix.

fdaClearances.description: Magma Spark: 808nm diode laser platform with ALD and LLD applicators for hair removal and permanent hair reduction (Fitzpatrick I-VI) and treatment of PFB. Special 510(k), predicate: K153566 (Magma System).

richContent.overview: The Magma Spark is the diode laser-only member of the Formatk Magma family. It uses the same 808nm ALD and LLD laser handpieces found on the full Magma platform but strips away the Nd:YAG laser and all IPL applicators. The result is a focused, purpose-built hair removal device at a lower price point than the full Magma.
richContent.howItWorks: Two 808nm diode laser handpieces, ALD (Advanced Laser Diode) and LLD (Large Laser Diode), deliver energy for hair removal. The LLD offers up to 35 J/cm². PowerMotion in-motion delivery enables single-pass treatments. MILO melanin meter provides objective skin typing. Golden-Touch contact cooling protects the epidermis during treatment.
typicalUses: Clinics focused exclusively on laser hair removal without needing skin rejuvenation capabilities
Practices wanting a purpose-built 808nm diode at a lower price than the full Magma
Entry point into the Formatk ecosystem with upgrade path to Alpha or Magma
richContent.keyFeatures: As a diode laser-only device, the Spark is classified as a purpose-built hair removal laser, unlike the hybrid Alpha and Magma. Same proven 808nm diode technology and PowerMotion delivery as its siblings, but without the added complexity and cost of IPL and Nd:YAG components. The Spark appears on some reseller sites as 'Alpha Magma Spark Pro' which can cause confusion with the separate Alpha System.

name: Alpha

skinTypes.displayText: All skin tones (808nm diode laser for hair removal across all skin types, 3D IPL with filters for skin treatments on lighter skin)

notes: Mid-range hybrid combining 808nm diode laser + 3D IPL on a single device. Hair removal is done via the LLD and ALD diode laser handpieces. These ARE real 808nm lasers. Two 3D IPL handpieces: L-530 (body, 530nm/650nm filters) and S-590 (face, 430nm/530nm/590nm filters) for skin rejuvenation, vascular/pigmented lesions, acne, and rosacea. Does NOT include the 1064nm Nd:YAG found on the full Magma. The '3D' in 3D IPL refers to three adjustable parameters: Energy, Pulse Duration, and Contact Cooling Intensity. Includes MILO digital melanin meter. Israeli manufacturer (Tirat Carmel), founded 2008. Distributed in North America by Aesthetic Management Partners and DermaSpark (Canada). Health Canada licensed. 20 million pulse handpiece life on diode.

fdaClearances.description: Operates under the Magma System clearance: multi-technology platform for 808nm diode laser and IPL. The Alpha is a configuration of the cleared Magma platform without the Nd:YAG applicator.

richContent.overview: Formatk's mid-range device positioned as 'Making Premium the New Standard.' Combines a genuine 808nm diode laser with 3D IPL technology on a single, smaller platform. The Alpha sits between the full Magma (which adds Nd:YAG) and the Spark (diode only). Unlike many hybrid systems where the hair removal component is IPL, the Alpha's primary hair removal handpieces (LLD and ALD) are real diode lasers.
richContent.howItWorks: The LLD handpiece delivers 808nm diode laser energy with up to 35 J/cm² for hair removal. Five treatment modes allow personalized protocols: standard, fast, and three PowerMotion modes that use high-fluence in-motion delivery for single-pass treatments. The ALD handpiece offers an alternative 808nm spot size. Two 3D IPL handpieces: L-530 (body, filters at 530nm and 650nm) for pigmented/vascular lesions and body hair removal on lighter skin, and S-590 (face, filters at 430nm, 530nm, 590nm) for acne, rosacea, and facial rejuvenation. '3D' means three independently adjustable parameters: energy, pulse duration, and contact cooling intensity, addressing the vasoconstriction problem of overcooling. MILO melanin meter provides in-vivo skin typing. Golden-Touch contact cooling protects the skin.
typicalUses: Clinics wanting real diode laser hair removal plus IPL skin treatments on one compact platform
Practices serving diverse skin types (Fitzpatrick I-VI)
Med spas and aesthetic clinics wanting to expand beyond hair removal without a second device
Clinics that don't need Nd:YAG vascular treatment (otherwise get the full Magma)
richContent.keyFeatures: The key distinction: the LLD diode handpiece IS a real 808nm laser, not IPL. The Alpha's 3D IPL handpieces offer independent control of energy, pulse duration, AND cooling temperature (most IPL systems only control energy and pulse duration). This addresses the overcooling/vasoconstriction problem where excessive cooling reduces treatment effectiveness. MILO melanin meter provides objective skin typing rather than visual Fitzpatrick assessment. No 1064nm Nd:YAG. Clinics needing vascular lesion treatment or dedicated darker-skin wavelength should consider the full Magma instead.

name: SmoothCool HR

skinTypes.displayText: Light to medium-dark skin tones (IPL with 700nm and 800nm long-pass filters for hair removal)

notes: Hair removal-focused IPL system. NOT a laser. Uses a dedicated HR handpiece with a large 10mm x 50mm spot size optimized for fast hair removal treatments. The 700nm and 800nm long-pass filters target deeper follicles. ATC sub-zero cooling to -10°C is the standout feature: eliminates the need for external Zimmer chiller. Also comes with 8 interchangeable SR filters (530nm, 560nm, 590nm, 640nm, 700nm, 800nm, plus 420(S) and 530(S) dual band-pass) enabling skin rejuvenation, vascular/pigmented lesion treatment, and acne treatment. Korean manufacturer (Jeisys Medical Inc., Seoul, founded 2001/2004), backed by Archimed ($8B healthcare investment firm). US distributor: Perigee Medical. NOTE: Completely different company from 'Guangzhou Jeisys Beauty Technology' (Chinese budget equipment).

SmoothCool HR System update: added handpieces (420nm(S), 560nm(S)) and filters (800nm, 530nm, 420nm). Predicate: K082911. Reference device: Lumenis Stellar M22 (K193500).
SmoothCool HR System update: added filters (640nm, 590nm, 545(V), 530(D), 500nm). Waveband 420-950nm. Predicate: K213484.

richContent.overview: Jeisys Medical's hair removal-focused IPL platform. The HR handpiece features a large 10mm x 50mm spot size with integrated ATC sub-zero cooling for fast, comfortable hair removal treatments. While primarily marketed for hair removal, the system also includes SR filters for skin rejuvenation versatility. This is NOT a laser. It is an IPL system, despite being classified under FDA product code GEX.
richContent.howItWorks: The system uses xenon flash lamp technology to generate broadband light. The HR handpiece uses 700nm and 800nm long-pass filters to target deeper hair follicles while bypassing superficial melanin. ATC (Advanced Cooling Technology) maintains precise skin surface temperature at sub-zero levels (-10°C) during treatment, enabling higher fluences with less pain. Fluence up to 65 J/cm². Pulse duration 1-60ms.
typicalUses: Clinics focused primarily on IPL hair removal with some skin rejuvenation capability
Practices wanting powerful IPL cooling without purchasing a separate Zimmer chiller
Clinics adding hair removal services alongside their existing treatment offerings
richContent.keyFeatures: ATC sub-zero cooling (-10°C) is the primary differentiator. No other IPL system offers built-in cooling this cold, eliminating the need for an external Zimmer chiller (~$15K+ savings). Large 10x50mm spot on the HR handpiece enables fast treatment of large body areas. 700nm filter targets deeper follicles, 800nm for even deeper penetration. Despite the 'HR' name, comes with 8 SR filters too. Legitimate Korean manufacturer backed by Archimed. Not to be confused with 'Guangzhou Jeisys Beauty Technology', a completely separate Chinese company.

name: SHR (Super Hair Removal)
whatItIs: SHR stands for Super Hair Removal. It is a delivery method, not a type of light source.
whyItMatters: SHR describes HOW energy is delivered (gradual heating with rapid pulses), not WHAT delivers it. SHR can be applied to real diode lasers (like Soprano) or to IPL machines. The term SHR alone does not tell you if you are getting a real laser treatment. You must ask what device powers the SHR - a $100,000 Soprano laser and a $3,000 generic IPL can both claim to offer SHR treatments.
askYourClinic: What is the brand and model of the device delivering SHR? Is it a Soprano laser or an IPL machine?

name: Moveo (DEKA In-Motion Technology)
whatItIs: Moveo is DEKA's proprietary in-motion delivery method for their Motus laser family. The sapphire-tipped handpiece glides continuously over the skin, delivering energy at lower fluence per pulse with gradual heating.
whyItMatters: Moveo is a delivery method exclusive to DEKA/Cartessa Motus laser systems (Motus AX, Motus AZ+, Motus PRO). Unlike SHR which can be used on any device, Moveo is hardware-specific - if a clinic says they use Moveo, they should have a genuine DEKA Motus device. The sapphire tip's flush contact reduces energy reflection from ~50% to nearly zero, meaning more energy reaches the follicle at lower power settings.
askYourClinic: What specific Motus model do you use? (Motus AX, AZ+, or PRO)

name: AFT (Advanced Fluorescence Technology)
whatItIs: AFT is Alma branded IPL technology that uses fluorescence to convert UV light to usable wavelengths.
whyItMatters: AFT is NOT a laser - it is a form of IPL. While Alma AFT technology is considered higher quality than generic IPL, it is still fundamentally an Intense Pulsed Light system, not a true laser. Results typically require more sessions than laser treatment.

name: BBL (BroadBand Light)
whatItIs: BBL is Sciton branded Intense Pulsed Light system, considered a premium IPL device.
whyItMatters: BBL is NOT a laser - it is a premium IPL system. While Sciton BBL is a high-quality device with good results for certain applications, it is fundamentally an Intense Pulsed Light system. For permanent hair reduction, true lasers typically provide faster results with fewer sessions.

name: E-Light
whatItIs: E-Light combines IPL with radiofrequency (RF) energy in a single device. Widely used as a generic term by budget manufacturers for IPL+RF combo machines.
whyItMatters: E-Light is NOT a laser. It is a combination of IPL and RF technology, often marketed with impressive-sounding names. The IPL component provides light energy while RF adds heat. Despite marketing claims, this is still fundamentally an IPL-based system, not a true laser. Note: not to be confused with the Syneron eLight, which is a specific clinical device from an established manufacturer using the same IPL+RF principle but with significantly higher build quality and proprietary elos technology.
askYourClinic: What is the brand and model of the E-Light device? Is it a Syneron eLight or a generic IPL+RF machine?

name: OPT (Optimal Pulse Technology)
whatItIs: OPT is a pulse delivery method used in IPL machines that provides consistent energy throughout the pulse.
whyItMatters: OPT is NOT a laser. It is a feature of some IPL machines. While OPT may improve the consistency of IPL treatments compared to traditional IPL, it is still fundamentally an Intense Pulsed Light system.

name: DPL (Dynamic Pulse Light)
whatItIs: DPL is a marketing term for certain IPL devices, suggesting improved pulse control.
whyItMatters: DPL is NOT a laser. It is another marketing name for IPL technology. Like OPT and E-Light, DPL is used to rebrand IPL devices with technical-sounding names. Regardless of the name, these are all Intense Pulsed Light systems, not true lasers.

name: 755nm Alexandrite
whatItIs: 755nm is the wavelength of Alexandrite lasers, one of the most effective for hair removal on lighter skin tones. If your clinic uses Alexandrite, it is a real laser.
whyItMatters: When used in a true laser system, 755nm Alexandrite is gold standard for hair removal on Fitzpatrick skin types I-IV. The wavelength is well-absorbed by melanin in hair follicles. Premium devices like GentleLase and GentleMax Pro use this wavelength.
askYourClinic: What brand is your 755nm Alexandrite laser?

name: 810nm Diode
whatItIs: 810nm (sometimes listed as 808nm) is the wavelength of diode lasers, the most common type used for hair removal. If your clinic uses an 810nm diode, it is a real laser.
whyItMatters: This is critical: the wavelength alone tells you almost nothing about treatment quality. A $3,000 machine from Alibaba uses 810nm. A $100,000 LightSheer uses 810nm. Same wavelength, drastically different results. The wavelength is just physics - what matters is the power output, spot size, pulse duration, cooling system, and overall engineering quality. When a clinic says 810nm diode laser, you must ask WHAT BRAND AND MODEL. A generic 810nm diode could be an excellent clinical device or a cheap import.
askYourClinic: What brand and model of 810nm diode laser do you use? How much did the device cost? How long have you had it?

name: 1064nm Nd:YAG
whatItIs: 1064nm is the wavelength of Nd:YAG lasers, specifically designed to be safe for darker skin tones. If your clinic uses Nd:YAG, it is a real laser.
whyItMatters: 1064nm penetrates deeper into the skin and is less absorbed by melanin in the epidermis, making it safe for Fitzpatrick skin types V-VI where other wavelengths would cause burns. Premium devices like GentleYAG use this wavelength. It is also used as the second wavelength in dual-wavelength systems.
askYourClinic: What brand is your Nd:YAG laser?

name: Dual Wavelength (755nm + 1064nm)
whatItIs: Dual wavelength systems combine 755nm Alexandrite and 1064nm Nd:YAG in a single device.
whyItMatters: Dual wavelength systems offer maximum versatility, able to treat all skin types with a single machine. The 755nm treats lighter skin effectively while 1064nm handles darker skin safely. Premium examples include GentleMax Pro and Elite iQ. These are genuine lasers and considered gold standard for clinics treating diverse clientele.
askYourClinic: What brand is your dual wavelength laser?

name: Tri-Wavelength (755nm + 808nm + 1064nm)
whatItIs: Tri-wavelength systems combine 755nm Alexandrite, 808nm Diode, and 1064nm Nd:YAG in a single device.
askYourClinic: What brand is your tri-wavelength laser?

name: Quad-Wavelength (755nm + 808nm + 940nm + 1064nm)
whatItIs: Quad-wavelength systems combine four diode wavelengths (typically 755nm, 808nm, 940nm, and 1064nm) into a single device. However, there are two very different implementations of this concept.
whyItMatters: Context matters more than the number of wavelengths. Budget Chinese-manufactured machines (typically $2,000-$5,000 from Alibaba) cram all four wavelengths into a single handpiece firing simultaneously. The 940nm addition over tri-wavelength machines is a spec-sheet differentiator to stand out in a crowded market of cheap imports (the clinical benefit over a quality tri-wavelength system is negligible). Premium systems like the Sciton OMNI also offer four wavelengths (760nm, 810nm, 940nm, 1060nm), but as separate dedicated handpieces that clinicians select based on patient skin type and treatment area. That is wavelength selection, not wavelength stacking, a fundamentally different and clinically meaningful approach. The critical issue is never the number of wavelengths. It is the quality of engineering behind them. A $3,000 quad-wavelength machine from Alibaba has four wavelengths on paper, but the power output per wavelength, pulse control precision, beam uniformity, and cooling system quality are not comparable to a premium system. When a clinic advertises '4-wavelength laser', ask what brand and model they are using and whether the wavelengths are in separate handpieces or a single combined handpiece. If it is not from a recognized manufacturer, the extra wavelength is a marketing talking point, not a clinical advantage.
askYourClinic: What is the brand and model of your 4-wavelength laser?

name: IPL (Intense Pulsed Light)
whatItIs: IPL stands for Intense Pulsed Light. It uses broad-spectrum light (multiple wavelengths at once) rather than a single focused wavelength like a laser.
whyItMatters: IPL is NOT a laser. While IPL can reduce hair growth, it is a fundamentally different technology. Lasers deliver a single, concentrated wavelength that precisely targets hair follicles. IPL scatters broad-spectrum light across the skin, making it less targeted and typically requiring more sessions for comparable results. Many clinics advertise 'laser hair removal' while actually using IPL devices. Branded versions of IPL include Sciton BBL, Alma AFT, E-Light, OPT, and DPL. All are IPL regardless of their marketing names.
askYourClinic: Do you use a laser or an IPL device? What is the specific brand and model?

name: VPL (Variable Pulsed Light)
whatItIs: VPL is Energist Medical Group's branded IPL technology, using multiple rapid micro-pulses per flash rather than a single burst of light. Manufactured in Swansea, UK since 1999 with over 3,500 units deployed worldwide.
whyItMatters: VPL is NOT a laser. It is a form of IPL. Clinicians sometimes call it a "VPL diode laser" but this is misleading. The word "diode" refers to the light source component, not a diode laser wavelength. Energist themselves describe VPL as built on Intense Pulsed Light technology. Unlike budget IPL imports, Energist is a legitimate manufacturer. But it is still IPL, not laser.

name: SFT (Smooth Flow Technology)
whatItIs: SFT is Rohrer Aesthetics' proprietary rapid-pulse delivery mode, exclusive to the EpiLaze hair removal system. In SFT mode, the laser delivers up to 10 pulses per second, allowing in-motion treatment of large body areas.
whyItMatters: Unlike SHR which can appear on any device from any manufacturer, SFT is hardware-specific to the Rohrer Aesthetics EpiLaze. If a clinic says they use SFT, they should have a genuine EpiLaze system. However, at least one Chinese manufacturer (MOONLIGHT) has copied Rohrer's marketing materials word for word, claiming 'our exclusive Smooth Flow Technology' on a generic tri-wavelength machine. If your clinic mentions SFT, ask to see the Rohrer Aesthetics branding on the device.
askYourClinic: Can I see the Rohrer Aesthetics logo on the machine? What is the model name?

name: USP (Ultra Short Pulse)
whatItIs: USP stands for Ultra Short Pulse. It is a patented delivery method developed by Cocoon Medical (Sinclair) that fires diode laser energy in pulses as short as 3ms. The ultra-short pulse duration reaches the optimal temperature to destroy the hair follicle's germination cells without heating the surrounding skin.
whyItMatters: USP is hardware-specific to Cocoon Medical devices (Primelase Excellence, Primelase HR, and Elysion Pro). Unlike generic terms like SHR which can appear on any machine, a clinic claiming USP technology should have a genuine Cocoon Medical device. However, as with other branded terms, Chinese manufacturers could copy the name. If you see USP indicated on a machine that isn't clearly Cocoon Medical or Sinclair branded, ask questions.
askYourClinic: What is the brand and model of your laser? USP is exclusive to Cocoon Medical devices (Primelase or Elysion Pro).
